issue.title: Add Stateful Signature (XMSS and LMS)
issue.body:
<!-- Please give a brief explanation of the purpose of this pull request. -->
Adds implementations of stateful signatures to liboqs for XMSS and LMS. The feature include new OQS APIs to generate key-pairs, signature generation, verification, and secret key state-management. Actual secret key storage is left up to the application.

This PR also includes an enhancement to OQS SHA2 API to allow handling updates with arbitrary length buffers.

<!-- Does this PR resolve any issue?  If so, please reference it using automatic-closing keywords like "Fixes #123." -->

<!-- Any PR adding a new feature is expected to contain a test; the test should be part of CI testing, preferably within the ".github/workflows" directory tree. Please add an explanation to the PR if/when (why) this cannot be done. -->

* [ Yes ] Does this PR change the list of algorithms available -- either adding, removing, or renaming? Does this PR otherwise change an API? (If so, PRs in fully supported downstream projects dependent on these, i.e., [oqs-provider](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider) and [OQS-OpenSSH](https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/openssh) will also need to be ready for review and merge by the time this is merged.)
OQS provider support is a separate and forthcoming feature. This is separated because of the need to manage the stateful of secret keys.

comment.body:
> Hey all! I've been playing around with this pr and I have a small feature request:
> 
> Would it make sense to create a public facing function that given a public key byte string, you are able to get the name of the parameter set via the oid?
> 
> The use-case I'm looking at is I don't want to have to define a new algorithm ID for each of the XMSS parametersets liboqs offers. Instead I want to to define an algorithim id for XMSS and XMSS^MT in my user application and then figure out which parameter set is being used based off of the key. Looking at the XMSS codebase (I haven't checked LMS yet) it looks like all public keys and secret keys are prefixed with an oid.
> 
> The function would look something like
> 
> ```
> char *OQS_SIG_STFL_name_from_public_key(unsigned char *pk)
> ```
> 
> What do you all think?

I think that's a great idea, let's do it.

comment.body:
> > So, this function would essentially be a parser? Only used for verify functionality?
> 
> It would be a parser that maps a public_key byte string to the string name of the parameter set. All the the `oid`s aren't exposed atm so there is no way for me to have a single algorithm id for XMSS nor XMSS^MT. I would need to break the `oqs_sig_stfl` api and add some of the XMSS includes as it currently stands.
> 
> Edit: It would be for taking a public key byte string that was transmitted to you, and then used to create the appropriate `sig_stfl_ctx`.

Ok, thanks for confirming my understanding of the ask. I think it would be good to get feedback from the gentleman, @ducnguyen-sb, that worked on the XMSS portion.

This background/history may be helpful as we consider your request. 
1. OQS APIs enumerates each variant of the given algorithm family
2. These enumerations allows selections at build time
3. Stateful Hash Based Signatures LMS, HSS and i think XMSS and XMSS MT can produce an impractical large number of variants. Many of which are infeasible to implement (due to usefulness, and performance). 
4. The limited set of supported HBS variants were selected based metrics such as key and signature generation time and number of signatures needed.

That said, your request is very reasonable from the stand point of the library only supporting signature verification. For this  use-case there is not a real need to limit signature verification capabilities.

I would suggest creating an issue which can be addressed separately.
Thanks.
